Although we were told by one of the volunteers at Hearst Castle that there names are Charm, Bloom, and Joy, I have discovered that "Although the Graces usually numbered three, according to the Spartans, Cleta, not Thalia, was the third, and other Graces are sometimes mentioned, including Auxo, Charis, Hegemone, Phaenna, and Pasithea. An ancient vase painting attests the following names: Antheia, Eudaimonia, Paidia, Pandaisia, Pannychis - all referring to the Charites as patronesses of amusement and festivities." (http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCharites)
california ca castle art naked nude artwork statues sansimeon hearstcastle marble hearst alabaster 18200mm

We were told their names are Charm, Bloom, and Joy - we since found out that is not at all accurate. However, there are many different interpretations or representations of the various Greek and Roman myths by various scholars, artist, and poets. *One may say they are the goddesses of charm, beauty, nature, human creativity and fertility. From youngest to oldest: Aglaea ("Splendor"), Euphrosyne ("Mirth"), and Thalia ("Good Cheer"). Or they may be Cleta rather than Thalia, or any of Auxo, Charis, Hegemone, Phaenna, or Pasithea. Or any three out of Antheia, Eudaimonia, Paidia, Pandaisia, Pannychis - all referring to the Charites as patronesses of amusement and festivities. Charisma, Persuasion, Sleep and Grace are also said to be of the Graces. *per my interpretation of the Wikipedia article of the Charities as they relate to the Graces.

california ca girls castle art nature beauty naked nude greek amusement artwork roman sleep joy statues charm grace mirth bloom wikipedia sansimeon hearstcastle marble fertility festivities hearst goddesses thalia graces charis charisma splendor persuasion alabaster paidia euphrosyne 18200mm charities cleta goodcheer charites antheia eudaimonia aglaea humancreativity pasithea hegemone patronesses auxo pannychis phaenna pandaisia

The three girls, Grace, Cleta and Phaenna. We were told their names are Charm, Bloom, and Joy - we since found out that is not at all accurate. Or any three out of Antheia, Eudaimonia, Paidia, Pandaisia, Pannychis - all referring to the Charites as patronesses of amusement and festivities. Charisma, Persuasion, Sleep and Grace are also said to be of the Graces. *per my interpretation of the Wikipedia article of the Charities as they relate to the Graces.
